channel.title: Australia
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012, Australian Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Clubs hold trump card in pokies pre-commitment saga
item.description: The Government's proposed trial on pre-commitment technology for poker machines in the ACT may never go ahead because the clubs are not legally forced to participate.

item.title: Expert warns against child mental health checks
item.description: A high-profile psychiatrist labels the Government's program to screen three-year-olds for mental health problems as "ridiculous" and potentially dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Hall

item.title: Outgoing bishop takes swipe at Vatican
item.description: A retiring Australian Catholic bishop has taken a swipe at the Vatican, urging his fellow clergy to continue the push for reform.
item.dc:creator: Lexi Metherell

item.title: D'Arcy and Monk's self-imposed social media ban
item.description: Swimmers Nick D'Arcy and Kenrick Monk have banned themselves from engaging in social media until after the Olympic Games.

item.title: Storm warning adds to WA residents' misery
item.description: West Australian residents are preparing for another violent storm as they clean up after yesterday's wild weather ripped through homes and left thousands without power.

item.title: Grant's good to go: Gallen
item.description: Blues skipper Paul Gallen says prop Tim Grant will be fit for Origin II in Sydney after the giant front rower limped out of training on Sunday.

item.title: Kerri-Anne Kennerley diagnosed with cancer
item.description: TV presenter Kerri-Anne Kennerley says she has breast cancer.

item.title: Afghan assignment: life with Australian troops
item.description: What's daily life like for Australian troops headed to Afghanistan? ABC reporter Kathy McLeish takes you behind the scenes on a stint embedded with Australian forces.

item.title: Greenhouse gases largely to blame for warming oceans: scientists
item.description: A new US-led study has concluded that warming ocean temperatures over the past 50 years are largely a man-made phenomenon.
item.dc:creator: Emily Woodgate

item.title: Map: Queen's Birthday honours around Australia
item.description: Who received Queen's Birthday honours near you? Find out using our map. The map shows all recipients of the honours, mapped by postcode.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Liddy

item.title: Senior diplomat sent to Libya to fight for lawyer's release
item.description: A senior Australian diplomat is heading to Libya to try to secure the release of an Australian lawyer accused of helping Moamar Gaddafi's son.

item.title: Government planning huge marine park expansion
item.description: The ABC has obtained an Environment Department plan that would turn Australia's oceans into the biggest marine conservation sanctuary in the world.
item.dc:creator: Conor Duffy

item.title: Controversial bioethicist tops Queen's honours
item.description: A Melbourne-based academic once likened to Hitler's deputy and described as "the most dangerous man on earth" is one of eight Australians to be awarded the top Queen's Birthday accolade.
item.dc:creator: Gemma Breen

item.title: Carr demands release of lawyer held in Libya
item.description: The Federal Government is calling for the immediate release of an Australian lawyer being detained in Libya, as international law experts raise serious concerns about her safety.

item.title: Bikie charged after body found in SA forest
item.description: A 51-year-old Finks bikie has been charged with murder over a body found in a shallow grave at Kuitpo Forest, south of Adelaide.

item.title: Good Samaritans rescue couple from sinking car
item.description: Four people jumped into chilly waters at the Gold Coast this morning to rescue an elderly couple whose car had crashed and was sinking into a canal.

item.title: Child exploitation arrests spark social networking warning
item.description: Queensland Police say a recent spate of child exploitation offences has highlighted the risks associated with social networking sites.

item.title: Australian killed in NZ car accident
item.description: A mathematics professor from Adelaide has died in New Zealand after his car hit the the entrance to a bridge near Fox Glacier.
item.dc:creator: Dominique Schwartz

item.title: Government pours $500m into Murray-Darling projects
item.description: The Federal Government has granted a request from New South Wales for $500 million to fund water infrastructure along the Murray-Darling river system.

item.title: Heffernan cleared over claims of homophobic attack
item.description: Police have cleared Senator Bill Heffernan of the alleged assault of an electorate officer at a Liberal party meeting on the NSW central coast.

item.title: Preschoolers to get mental health checks
item.description: Australian preschoolers are set to be screened for early signs of mental illness as part of a voluntary Government-funded program.

item.title: Resurgent Wallabies outrun Wales
item.description: Australia rebounded from a shock loss to Scotland with a somewhat unconvincing 27-19 win over Six Nations champion Wales in a bustling encounter at Lang Park on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Adrian Crawford

item.title: Australian lawyer for Gaddafi's son held in Libya
item.description: An Australian lawyer working for the International Criminal Court has been detained in Libya for trying to pass "dangerous letters" to the son of former leader Moamar Gaddafi.

item.title: Four Corners defends Captain Emad whistleblower
item.description: The ABC's Four Corners strongly rejects claims made by The Australian newspaper that an informer who assisted the program's investigation into alleged people smuggling kingpin Captain Emad is "unreliable".

item.title: Rattled NSW towns undamaged by quakes
item.description: Earthquake-hit communities in north-west New South Wales have escaped with little more than some jangled nerves and a few cracked windows.

item.title: Thomson legal bill cost Labor almost $350k
item.description: An internal Labor document has confirmed the party paid nearly $350,000 dollars of federal MP Craig Thomson's legal costs last year.

item.title: Opposition toughens refugee policy
item.description: Asylum seekers who arrive in Australia without a passport or identity papers are being targeted in the federal Opposition's new refugee policy.

item.title: Australia pledges millions in education aid to Burma
item.description: Australia is set to become the world's largest donor to education in Burma, with plans in place to train 20,000 teachers over the next four years.

item.title: Swan slams 'deplorable' Greenpeace anti-coal ad
item.description: Federal Treasurer Wayne Swan has condemned a Greenpeace ad in an Indian newspaper that warns against investing in Queensland coal projects.

item.title: Dollar ends volatile week lower
item.description: It has been a soft end to the week for the Australian dollar after it briefly reached parity with the greenback.

item.title: Qantas shares nosedive to record closing low
item.description: Qantas shares have slipped to a record closing low of 97 cents, capping a dramatic week in which $1.1 billion was wiped off the airline's market value.

item.title: No decision made on Gallipoli lottery
item.description: The Government says no decision has been made about whether a ballot will be used to determine who can go to Gallipoli for centenary commemorations.

item.title: Animals' hendra test results inconclusive
item.description: Biosecurity Queensland says the latest hendra virus test results on two horses and a dog are not conclusive.

item.title: Home loan approvals tick higher
item.description: Official figures show home loan approvals rose in April, in line with expectations that interest rates would be cut in May.

item.title: RBA chief says Australians too pessimistic
item.description: Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens says Australians are too pessimistic about the state of the economy and should be more positive about the country's prospects.

item.title: The kill chain: Australia's drone war
item.description: A senior ADF officer has revealed details of how Australia deploys Israeli-owned drones for battlefield surveillance and to target anti-government Islamic fighters in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Mark Corcoran

item.title: Bush foods boom feeding high-end diners
item.description: Celebrity chefs in their high-end restaurants have cottoned on to the bitter and unique flavours of Australian bush foods.

item.title: Four Indonesian people smugglers freed from jail
item.description: The Federal Government has released four more Indonesian people smugglers who say they were children when they were arrested.

item.title: Star casino head falls on his sword
item.description: The chairman of Echo Entertainment - which runs Sydney's Star casino - has resigned following pressure from billionaire shareholder James Packer.

item.title: Australian market loses ground
item.description: The local share market lost ground this morning after the US Federal Reserve offered few indications that it is planning further stimulus.

item.title: Major banks follow suit on rate cuts
item.description: National Australia Bank has joined the other big banks in lowering interest rates after the RBA's official cut earlier this week.

item.title: Hockey wants debate about raising retirement age
item.description: Shadow treasurer Joe Hockey says Australia should have a debate about proposals to increase the retirement age to 70.

item.title: Australia's ability to hunt smugglers questioned
item.description: A prominent lawyer who has defended people smugglers has shed light on the difficulty authorities face mounting a case against them after "Captain Emad" was able to flee the country unchallenged.

item.title: Divers worried as cuttlefish fail to show up
item.description: Divers worried as giant Australian cuttlefish are yet to been seen in their usual numbers in upper Spencer Gulf in SA this season.

item.title: Customs to cut jobs at 'low risk' ports
item.description: Customs is planning to slash staff from 14 offices across the country, according to an internal document obtained by the ABC.

item.title: Son suspect in father's Adelaide hills murder
item.description: A teenager is being investigated over the murder of his father in the Adelaide hills.

item.title: Olympic boss won't rule out axing swimmers
item.description: Nick D'Arcy and Kenrick Monk have arrived back in Australia amid suggestions they could be dumped from the Olympic squad for posting a photo of themselves brandishing guns on Facebook.

item.title: Prominent lawyer appeals against Corby sentence cut
item.description: One of Indonesia's most prominent lawyers has lodged a court challenge against Schapelle Corby's reduced prison term.

item.title: High Commissioner visit angers PNG deputy PM
item.description: Papua New Guinea's deputy prime minister has complained about a visit by Australia's High Commissioner to his electorate.
item.dc:creator: Liam Fox

item.title: Jobs, stimulus hopes see shares extend rally
item.description: The Australian dollar climbed closer to parity and the share market posted solid gains today after the release of better-than-expected jobs data.

item.title: D'Arcy and Monk under fire over gun photos
item.description: Nick D'arcy and Kenrick Monk are in hot water with Swimming Australia and the Australian Olympic Committee after posting inappropriate photos on Facebook.

item.title: Australia lifts sanctions against Burma
item.description: Foreign Affairs Minister Bob Carr says Australia will lift its remaining sanctions against Burma to encourage further democratic reforms.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Daniel

item.title: AFP close to wrapping up Slipper probe
item.description: Federal Police say they are "very close" to wrapping up their investigation into travel rort claims against suspended Federal Parliamentary Speaker Peter Slipper.

item.title: AFP to fight former agent's AWB allegations
item.description: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Tony Negus says the agency will defend itself against allegations made by the head of the probe into the AWB oil-for-food scandal.

item.title: Audit raises school solar power safety concerns
item.description: An audit of the Federal Government's solar schools initiative has raised safety concerns about solar power systems.

item.title: Burke takes control of Alpha reef mine study
item.description: The Federal Government will take over the environmental assessment of Queensland's Alpha Coal Project after a tug-of-war with the State Government.

item.title: Construction caught in 2-year downturn
item.description: The construction industry has shrunk every month for the past two years, new figures show.

item.title: AFP says Captain Emad has fled the country
item.description: AFP Commissioner Tony Negus has revealed an alleged people smuggler, known as Captain Emad, fled Australia a day after being the focus of an ABC TV Four Corners story.
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Iron bar killers jailed over attack
item.description: A man and his half-brother have been jailed for violently killing another man with an iron bar and stomping on the body.

item.title: Diggers help uncover Afghan arms cache
item.description: Australian and Afghan soldiers have discovered a weapons cache in Afghanistan, including over 100,000 rounds of ammunition.

item.title: Unemployment rate rises despite jobs boost
item.description: Australia's unemployment rate rises to 5.1 per cent despite the creation of nearly 40,000 full-time jobs, as more people hunt for work.

item.title: Talk of stimulus boosts Australian stocks
item.description: The Australian share market jumped at the open amid speculation that central banks in the United States and the eurozone would take steps to stimulate their economies.

item.title: Wallabies unfazed on who's favourites
item.description: Robbie Deans says he does not care whether or not the Wallabies are favourites to win Saturday's opening Test against Wales at Lang Park.
item.dc:creator: Luke Pentony

item.title: Investor wins legal challenge over lost Trio funds
item.description: An elderly woman who lost her life savings in the collapse of Trio Capital has succeeded in a legal claim against a financial planner.

item.title: High costs 'threaten mining industry'
item.description: Big business is warning that a trillion-dollar capital investment pipeline is being threatened by the high-cost nature of the Australian economy.
item.dc:creator: Peter Ryan

item.title: Junior firefighter turns up to lend a hand
item.description: Firefighters were offered a little extra help when they were called to a blaze at an old pub in the Melbourne suburb of Flemington last night.

item.title: AFP agent 'offered promotion' to close AWB probe
item.description: The head of the federal police probe into the AWB oil-for-food scandal says he was offered a promotion to shut down the investigation into Iraqi kickbacks.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Hall

item.title: Thomson tabloid TV war sparks privacy concerns
item.description: Two tabloid TV shows are squabbling over an interview with a former prostitute who now says she never had sex with MP Craig Thomson.

item.title: Child care changes will take time: Gillard
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard says the Government is determined to address child care affordability concerns, but appears to be in no hurry to make any changes to the system.
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Unemployment rate tipped to rise
item.description: Recent job losses in retailing, finance and manufacturing are expected to lead to an unemployment increase in May when official figures are released today.

item.title: Shorten may intervene in teachers pay dispute
item.description: The Federal Government has not ruled out intervening in the Victorian teachers pay dispute if the stand-off continues.

item.title: Indigenous party wants national service
item.description: Australia's first Indigenous political party will run in the Northern Territory election on a platform of compulsory national service in the Territory.

item.title: Roads reopen as flood threat eases
item.description: There is good news for flood-weary Gippsland communities in eastern Victoria with major roads in the region reopening.

item.title: Indonesia demands answers over smuggler's visa
item.description: Indonesia has asked Australia to explain how an alleged people smuggler, known as Captain Emad, was given a refugee protection visa.
item.dc:creator: Matt Brown

item.title: Gippsland residents told to evacuate as water rises
item.description: Several communities in eastern Victoria's Gippsland region are facing an anxious night as waters continue to rise, threatening hundreds of homes and forcing evacuations.

item.title: Qld Health payroll debacle to cost $1.2b
item.description: An independent review has found it will cost at least $1.25 billion and take seven years to fix Queensland Health's failed payroll system.

item.title: Gillard calls snap meeting on child care fee hikes
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard calls a snap meeting with child care stakeholders as figures show fees have risen by 11 per cent in the past year.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Hawley

item.title: Shares tick higher after GDP surprise
item.description: The share market wavered today as investors weighed the positive news in the latest Australian economic growth figures against continuing worries about global conditions.

item.title: Court told of defamatory remarks against FWA's Lawler
item.description: Fair Work Australia vice-president Michael Lawler has hired a lawyer to represent him in a court battle over the future of the Health Services Union (HSU), after allegations he has been defamed.

item.title: ACCC urges extension of price-signalling ban
item.description: The competition watchdog says it is disappointed the Federal Government did not extend new anti-price fixing laws to petrol retailers.

item.title: Wilkie challenges Government on whistleblower bill
item.description: Federal Independent MP Andrew Wilkie says he will introduce a private member's bill on whistleblowing if the Federal Government does not pass legislation by the end of August.

item.title: Carr invites Suu Kyi to visit Australia
item.description: Foreign Minister Bob Carr has held talks with Burma's opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi at her home in Rangoon.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Daniel

item.title: Swan hits back at economic 'doomsayers'
item.description: Federal Treasurer Wayne Swan has described the latest economic growth figures as "stunning" and has declared that they should put an end to the "doomsayers".
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Wadeye given $7m over discrimination claims
item.description: The remote NT Aboriginal community of Wadeye has received a payout of $7 million from the Federal Government over racial discrimination claims.

item.title: Government to speed up Native Title claims
item.description: The Federal Government announces an overhaul of Native Title laws, but stops short of reversing the onus of proof on traditional owners.

item.title: Treasurer hails 'exceptional' economic growth
item.description: Wayne Swan says "stunning" GDP figures paint a picture of "exceptional growth" after news the economy grew twice as fast as expected in the first quarter of the year.

item.title: Al Kuwaiti: the man behind the boats
item.description: Take a look at the story of Abu Ali al Kuwaiti, the smuggler believed to be behind a boatload of 97 asylum seekers who never made it to Australia.
item.dc:creator: Matt Brown

item.title: Law reform urged after three homebirth tragedies
item.description: A coroner is urging changes to laws on homebirths after investigating the deaths of three newborns in SA where the same midwife Lisa Barrett was present.

item.title: High Court to hear asylum detention claim
item.description: A Sri Lankan asylum seeker facing indefinite detention because of an adverse security assessment has won his bid for an urgent hearing in the High Court.

item.title: Penguins missing from SA rehab site
item.description: Workers at the Penguin Centre on SA's Granite Island are baffled as to what has happened to two penguins undergoing rehabilitation there.

item.title: Big banks 'ignoring' Swan's tough talk
item.description: Wayne Swan tries to ramp up pressure on the big four banks after yesterday’s Reserve Bank cut, but the Opposition says the banks are ignoring him
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Economic growth 'as good as it will get'
item.description: Official figures to be released today are expected to show Australia's economy grew at a faster rate in the first three months of the year, but economists are warning growth may slow.

item.title: Wilpena resort sold to native title holder
item.description: The Adnyamathanha people have bought the multi-million-dollar Wilpena Pound resort in SA.

item.title: NSW storms cut power to thousands of homes
item.description: The New South Wales State Emergency Service is still working to clear a back-log of calls after yesterday's wild storm.

item.title: Venus completes transit of the Sun
item.description: Time has run out for millions around the world to watch Venus pass in front of the Sun in an astronomical event that will not be seen for another 105 years.

item.title: Lakes residents prepare for flooding
item.description: Residents in townships along the Gippsland Lakes are being told to prepare for possible flooding tonight.

item.title: Newman slams 'rogue' Burke in reef mine spat
item.description: Queensland Premier Campbell Newman hits out at Environment Minister Tony Burke in the latest verbal salvo over the approval process for a multi-billion dollar mine project.

item.title: Scots sink Wallabies at the death
item.description: Scotland's miserly defence and a penalty goal after the siren saw Australia fall 9-6 in sodden conditions in Newcastle.
item.dc:creator: Adrian Crawford

item.title: Dream spawns Black Caviar's spandex suit
item.description: The idea to create a spandex body suit for champion mare Black Caviar came to a NSW man while he was sleeping.

item.title: People smuggling crackdown fails to catch ringleaders
item.description: Despite the massive resources being used to tackle people smugglers, less than half of those arrested by Australian authorities are convicted and most of the ringleaders escape untouched.

item.title: Greens' Brown farewells political life
item.description: Former Greens leader Bob Brown delivers a farewell speech, touching on his past, future, the political landscape and his links to Jimi Hendrix.
item.dc:creator: Sabra Lane

item.title: Rate cut boosts local markets
item.description: The RBA's decision to cut interest rates helps Australian stocks rise despite a big drop in the share price of Qantas.

item.title: Current account widens as exports shrink
item.description: The latest current account figures show the resources investment boom is not yet boosting economic growth.

item.title: QR National to cut 500 jobs
item.description: Australia's largest rail freight company QR National will cut more than 500 jobs as part of a restructure.

item.title: Details emerge of asylum seekers lost at sea
item.description: In 2010, 97 asylum seekers disappeared in the ocean en route to Australia, and the people smugglers involved lied about the loss to collect payments from families.

item.title: Thousands without power as rivers keep rising
item.description: Emergency authorities say eight major rivers in Victoria's Gippsland are continuing to rise, threatening hundreds of properties.

item.title: RBA calms nerves with another rate cut
item.description: The Reserve Bank has moved to calm rattled households and non-mining sectors of the economy by shaving 25 basis points from the cash rate, with Bank of Queensland the first to cut after the announcement.

item.title: Baby drowned in unfenced home pool
item.description:
An inquest has been shown chilling vision of the moments before a baby drowned in a family pool.

Home security camera vision from January 2010 showed one-year-old Bryce Ashton Eddleston crawling through some concertina doors and onto the edge of the pool at Salisbury Heights, then falling in.

item.title: Gallop steps down as ARLC chief
item.description: David Gallop said the Australian Rugby League Commission wanted a fresh approach so there was no point hanging around.

item.title: Tax office seeks millions from cult leader and associates
item.description: The tax office will increase its civil claim against the fugitive leader of Agape Ministries, Rocco Leo.

item.title: Burke slams 'shambolic' reef mine approval
item.description: The Commonwealth threatens to seize control of major environmental approvals from Queensland, amid a public war of words over a multi-billion dollar mine project.
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Accountant alleged to have stolen $1.3m
item.description:
An Adelaide accountant is alleged to have stolen $1.3 million from his employer.

Demetres Zacharoudes is accused of making six illegal transfers totalling $1.09 million from company bank accounts into his own between last October and April of this year.

It is further alleged police found him with nearly $12,000 of stolen cash in April.

Salary sacrifice organisation EPAC Salary Solutions is seeking compensation for the loss.

item.title: Teen school arsonist avoids jail term
item.description: A teenager who caused a $1 million school fire has cried and hugged his family as he avoided going to jail.

item.title: Qantas shares plummet after profit warning
item.description: Qantas shares have dived to an all-time low after the airline announced it expected full-year profit before tax to fall as much as 90 per cent due to losses in its international business.

item.title: Indonesia angry over smuggling kingpin's visa
item.description: Revelations that people smugglers posed as asylum seekers to get themselves into Australia have sparked an angry backlash in Jakarta.
item.dc:creator: Matt Brown

item.title: Copper thieves ripping up live underground cables
item.description: Thieves in Adelaide have ripped up live underground wiring, with authorities warning it left motorists at risk.

item.title: Government orders probe into people smuggler claims
item.description: Immigration Minister Chris Bowen orders an investigation into revelations that a people-smuggling kingpin posed as an asylum seeker to get himself into Australia.
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Survey shows Australians support foreign labour
item.description: A new survey shows a majority of Australians support the use of foreign workers to address labour shortages, but are also opposed to large-scale foreign investment.

item.title: Economists divided on Reserve's next move
item.description: Economists are split three ways in their predictions about what the Reserve Bank will decide to do when they meet today.

item.title: Race on to heritage list Cape York Peninsula
item.description: Environmentalists say the coming months will decide whether Cape York Peninsula will become Australia's next mining province, or whether governments will preserve its unique and vast ecosystem.

item.title: Tourism Australia launches $250m ad blitz in China
item.description: The Federal Government has chosen Shanghai to launch its latest global tourism campaign.

item.title: Mayne to contest Melbourne by-election
item.description: High-profile shareholder activist and Crikey founder Stephen Mayne has announced he will run as an independent in the by-election for the state seat of Melbourne.

item.title: Snowsill misses Olympic selection
item.description: Defending Olympic triathlon champion Emma Snowsill will appeal after being left out of Australia's team for the London Games.

item.title: Buyer comes forward for Hastie business
item.description: Administrators sifting through the collapse of Hastie Group have announced the sale of a company in the group that is expected to save 134 jobs.
item.dc:creator: Peter Ryan

item.title: Shares tumble as investors rush for the exit
item.description: The share market drops to its lowest level in nearly seven months, wiping $23 billion from the market as fears gather that the world's top economies will fall back into recession.

item.title: Abbott likens carbon tax to python squeeze
item.description: The Federal Government has accused Opposition Leader Tony Abbott of "crab-walking" away from his carbon tax claims.
item.dc:creator: Simon Cullen

item.title: Nine breached code in NRL pokies commentary
item.description: The broadcasting regulator has sanctioned the Nine Network for claiming criticisms of proposed poker machine laws by commentators during an NRL game were not scripted.

item.title: Study busts meat-eating myths
item.description: A new Australian study has busted some commonly held beliefs about the importance of meat, particularly for pregnant women and children.

item.title: Inflation, jobs data 'boost case to cut rates'
item.description: A closely watched measure of inflation remains below the Reserve Bank's target as new figures suggest unemployment may rise, leaving room for the RBA to ease the cash rate tomorrow.

item.title: Boat carrying 85 asylum seekers intercepted
item.description: An asylum seeker boat carrying 85 passengers and three crew has been stopped north-west of Ashmore Island.

item.title: Cult leader ordered to pay $420k to stroke victim
item.description: Cult leader Rocco Leo has been ordered to pay a former parishioner $420,000, in a ruling by the Adelaide District Court.

item.title: Investors braced as shares tumble at open
item.description: The Australian share market slipped below 4,000 points this morning amid fears that the world's major economies will fall back into recession.

item.title: Contented seal heads up the Murray
item.description: A New Zealand fur seal has found an unusual resting spot at Currency Creek, upstream from the mouth of the Murray.

item.title: Abbott slips in Nielsen poll but Coalition still leading
item.description: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott's popularity has dropped sharply in the latest Nielsen opinion poll, but the Coalition would still win convincingly if an election was held today.

item.title: Native Title changes flagged on Mabo anniversary
item.description: Attorney-General Nicola Roxon has flagged changes to the native title system on the 20th anniversary of Australia's historic Mabo ruling.

item.title: Blues call up Panther Grant
item.description: New South Wales has selected Penrith prop Tim Grant to make his debut in State of Origin II against Queensland.

item.title: Child care costs up 11pc, union says
item.description: The Government must overhaul its childcare funding system to ease financial pressure on staff and parents, the union says.

item.title: Hundreds honour Bomber Command in Canberra
item.description: Australians who served with Bomber Command during World War II have been honoured at a ceremony in Canberra.

item.title: Human remains found in bush grave
item.description: Police have confirmed they have found human remains in a remote bush grave in Western Australia's south-west.

item.title: New domestic violence laws target emotional abuse
item.description: New domestic violence laws will make it an offence to harm pets, cut people off from their family or withhold financial support.

item.title: Migrant police brutality case highlights growing trend
item.description: Victoria Police spent almost $500,000 on a court case involving allegations of police brutality against two migrants.
item.dc:creator: Hagar Cohen

item.title: Mabo - a timeline
item.description: News Online takes a look at the lead-up to the landmark Mabo decision and how it changed the face of Australian society.

item.title: Demons survive to record Bombers boilover
item.description: Melbourne avoided its worst season start in 93 years by securing its first points of the season in a stunning one-goal upset of Essendon.

item.title: Concerns schools failing to recognise deadly allergies
item.description: The parents of a Victorian teenager who died on school camp say they are concerned Australian schools are failing to realise that food allergies can kill.

item.title: Job insecurity could spark health crisis, experts warn
item.description:
Mental health advocates say that stress and anxiety caused by job insecurity is threatening to become a major public health problem in Australia.

Beyond Blue, one of the nation's most prominent mental health organisations, says job insecurity is one of the leading risk factors for depression and even heart disease.

With 40 per cent of the Australian workforce in insecure work arrangements, Beyond Blue CEO Kate Carnell says it has become a serious public health problem.

item.title: UN report scathing of Barrier Reef plan
item.description: UNESCO releases its highly-anticipated report on the Great Barrier Reef, warning that rapid development is threatening the pristine marine park.

item.title: Aussie jailed in South Africa for hiring hitman
item.description: A South African court has sentenced an Australian man to nine years in jail for hiring a man to kill the father of a woman he was obsessed with.
item.dc:creator: Ginny Stein

item.title: Fire forces hundreds to evacuate sports club
item.description: Hundreds had to evacuate Sydney's Maroubra Seals Sports Club after the building caught fire, causing part of the roof to collapse.

item.title: Belinda Neal targeted over Mariners debt
item.description:
Former federal Labor MP Belinda Neal is being pursued by the tax office over her time as a director of the A-League's Central Coast Mariners.

For six years, the former member for Robertson on the New South Wales Central Coast served as a director of the Mariners.

The Australian Tax Office has submitted a claim for more than a $1.4 million in unpaid income tax for the Central Coast club going back to 2009.

item.title: Snowfalls bring early start to ski season
item.description: The official ski season has opened a week early after 30cm snowfalls in NSW's Snowy Mountains.

item.title: Woman's body found in backyard grave
item.description: Police say two people killed a woman and buried her body on her parent's property in Sydney's south-west.

item.title: Clubs to be sold off as Fitness First slims down
item.description: Gym chain Fitness First will sell almost a quarter of its Australian clubs as part of a restructure.

item.title: Shares, dollar struggle amid China worries
item.description: Hopes that weak manufacturing data from China may prompt more economic stimulus measures there helped the Australian share market claw back some earlier losses.

item.title: Police want Gold Coast Finks declared criminal organisation
item.description: Queensland Police have moved to declare the Gold Coast arm of the Finks Motorcycle Club a criminal organisation.

item.title: Manufacturers struggle in Australia and China
item.description: The manufacturing sectors of Australia and China both slowed last month, new figures show, as global economic uncertainties weakened demand.

item.title: FFA 'betrayed' Queensland clubs
item.description: FFA has 'betrayed' Queensland's failed A-League clubs, according to the independent commissioner of Clive Palmer's Football Australia.

item.title: Conflict of interest claims in China farmland deal
item.description: Trade Minister Craig Emerson has rejected claims his support for Chinese investment in northern Australia has been influenced by the reported business interests of former Labor prime minister Bob Hawke.

item.title: Rate cut fails to boost property prices
item.description: The Reserve Bank's move to slash the cash rate to its lowest level in more than two years did little to prop up house prices in May, new figures show.

item.title: Deputy Speaker decries feral politics
item.description: Deputy Speaker Anna Burke says parliamentary standards are probably the lowest they have been in her 14 years in politics.

item.title: Syrian diplomat's daughter forced to leave Canberra school
item.description: The daughter of a Syrian diplomat expelled from Australia this week has been forced to end her schooling just months before sitting Year 12 exams.

item.title: Fair Work announces minimum wage rise
item.description: Fair Work Australia has announced a 2.9 per cent increase to the minimum wage, boosting the weekly income of more than 1.4 million workers to $606.40.

item.title: Fairfax journos return to work
item.description: More than 800 Fairfax journalists in New South Wales and Victoria have returned to work this morning after walking off the job for two days.

item.title: Qantas boss accused of misleading committee
item.description: Qantas chief executive officer Alan Joyce has been accused of misleading a Senate committee about his decision to lock out workers last year.

item.title: Accused Bali bomb-maker pleads for leniency
item.description: Accused Bali bomb-maker Umar Patek has read his final defence in a Jakarta court, denying major involvement in the attacks.

item.title: Japanese midget sub to go on display
item.description: A piece of Australia's war history which was salvaged from the bottom of Sydney Harbour is to go on public display today.

item.title: Sheep plunge onto highway after truck crash
item.description: Terrified motorists ploughed into sheep which had plunged onto a busy highway after the truck which was carrying them crashed on an overpass in Melbourne last night.

item.title: Queen awards Howard Order of Merit
item.description: The Queen has made former prime minister John Howard one of only 24 living holders of the Order of Merit.
item.dc:creator: Philip Williams

item.title: Fels targets Cabcharge in taxi inquiry
item.description: The $1 billion Cabcharge company is under the spotlight as Professor Allan Fels reports back on an inquiry into

item.title: Unrest grows over series of Defence cuts and delays
item.description: A retired senior Army officer has added his voice to the growing list of parties concerned by the Government's decision to delay and cut key Defence initiatives and bring forward a review.

item.title: Taxi inquiry calls for knowledge test, fare hike
item.description: An inquiry has called for a major shake-up of Victoria's taxi industry, including a strict local knowledge test for drivers and a peak-hour fare increase.

item.title: Prison guards take action over colleague's sentence
item.description: New South Wales prison guards will take industrial action on Friday after one of their Newcastle colleagues was given a jail sentence for assaulting an inmate.

item.title: Shares dip, dollar extends losses
item.description: The Australian share market has dipped and the dollar has fallen to a six-month low against the greenback amid fears Spain may need a bailout.

item.title: Commissioner warns against racism in jobs row
item.description: Race Discrimination Commissioner Helen Szoke has warned against allowing a visa deal for international workers to be caught up in xenophobia and racism.

item.title: Australia to take control in Uruzgan
item.description: Australia will take over the leadership of international troops in Afghanistan's Uruzgan province at the end of this year, ahead of the transition process to Afghan control.

item.title: Mixed business spending points to weak GDP
item.description: Economists believe the increasingly poor performance of non-mining sectors and cuts to government spending are weighing on economic growth.

item.title: Abbott, Xenophon unite over online gambling changes
item.description: The Federal Opposition has joined forces with independent Senator Nick Xenophon and vowed to block any attempt to loosen restrictions on online gambling.

item.title: Ratings downgrade as SA budget makes deep cuts
item.description: SA Treasurer Jack Snelling has made deep cuts in his second state budget, and seen a ratings downgrade to AA+.

item.title: Chinese food deal a 'threat to sovereignty'
item.description: The Federal Government is considering opening up land for farming in northern Australia as part of a deal to export food to China.

item.title: Olympic Dam expansion may fall at last hurdle
item.description: Analysts say the future of BHP Billiton's proposed $30 billion Olympic Dam mine expansion in South Australia seems increasingly uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Michael Janda

item.title: Consumer caution the new normal: David Jones
item.description: David Jones says consumers remain gloomy despite sales conditions steadying since the eurozone's debt problems sparked a slowdown in spending at the department store last year.

item.title: Carr defends Government's handling of Assange
item.description: Foreign Minister Bob Carr has defended the amount of help the Government has given to WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange.

item.title: Tight-lipped Savage appeals Olympic axing
item.description: Axed Olympic rower Pippa Savage has appealed the decision to drop her from the Australian team, but she won't answer questions about the controversy.

item.title: Tougher sentences for tobacco smugglers
item.description: The Federal Government plans to introduce tougher penalties for tobacco smugglers.

item.title: Tent embassy protesters appear in court
item.description: About 30 people who were charged after police broke up a tent embassy in Brisbane's Musgrave Park have appeared in court this morning.

item.title: Digger returns to duty after Afghan heroics
item.description: Defence Chief David Hurley says an Australian soldier credited with saving an Afghan soldier's life has returned to light duties after being wounded in a bomb blast in Afghanistan.

item.title: Millions shifted from UAE as Hastie collapsed
item.description: The ABC has learned that up to 1,500 Hastie Group workers in the United Arab Emirates may have lost their entitlements because more than $3 million was transferred to Australia before the company collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Peter Ryan

item.title: Shares, dollar drop amid red flags on Spain
item.description: Australian stocks drop more than 1 per cent and the dollar falls to a six-month low against its US counterpart amid fears Spain may need a bailout.

item.title: MP throws mud at $3m defence huts
item.description: A federal MP is accusing the Defence Department of wasting money by spending millions of dollars on mud huts.

item.title: Kennett denies casino conflict with depression work
item.description: Former Victorian premier Jeff Kennett insists his plan to join the board of Sydney's Star Casino does not undermine his work at Beyond Blue.
item.dc:creator: Jean Edwards

item.title: Farmers at odds over free range definition
item.description: Feathers are flying as the Australian Egg Corporation and consumer group Choice go beak to beak over what constitutes a "free range" chicken.

item.title: Treasurer lands punch on SA public sector
item.description:
A further 1,000 public sector job losses will be outlined in the South Australian budget today.

They will be axed over three years and are expected to produce a saving of $166 million.

The cuts will be shared across government agencies and are on top of those made in previous state budgets, including more than 3,700 job losses announced in 2010.

item.title: Australia slips in competiveness rankings
item.description: Australia has slipped down the rankings in a global study of business competitiveness for the second year in a row.

item.title: Strike thins out Fairfax titles
item.description: Readers of Fairfax newspapers will see a thinner version this morning after hundreds of journalists walked off the job yesterday afternoon.

item.title: Assange considers next move after losing appeal
item.description: Julian Assange's lawyers get two weeks to consider their next move after the Wikileaks founder's appeal against extradition to Sweden was rejected by the UK's Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Millar

item.title: Gillard faces down mining bosses
item.description: Julia Gillard has thrown down the gauntlet to mining bosses, telling them face-to-face that they don't own the nation's resources and Australians deserve their share.
item.dc:creator: Tom Iggulden

item.title: Assange loses appeal against extradition
item.description: Britain's Supreme Court has ruled Australian-born WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange can be extradited to Sweden to face questioning over sexual assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Rachael Brown

item.title: Carr dismisses 'absurd' breach of conduct claims
item.description: Foreign Affairs Minister Bob Carr has appeared before a Senate Estimates hearing to answer questions over whether he has breached ministerial standards.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Woodley

item.title: Aussie brew beats Germans at their own game
item.description: An Australian couple has beaten German beer makers at their own game by taking out a top international brewing prize.

item.title: BHP Billiton freezes major project approvals
item.description: The world's biggest miner, BHP Billiton, says it is freezing all board-level major project approvals for six months.
item.dc:creator: Michael Janda

item.title: Expert committee to monitor CSG permits
item.description: Two independent MPs have welcomed the passing of legislation that will see the establishment of an expert scientific committee for coal seam gas and coal mining.

item.title: Consumers curb spending in shops and online
item.description: Retail sales fell for the first time in 10 months in April, with the promise of a cut to the cash rate doing little to encourage consumers to open their wallets at the shops.

item.title: Blog: Julian Assange loses extradition appeal
item.description: London's Supreme Court has ruled that Australian WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange should be extradited to Sweden to face allegations of sexual assault. See how events unfolded on our live blog.

item.title: Australians to outstrip others in internet use
item.description: A new report is predicting 90 per cent of Australians will be using the internet by 2016.

item.title: Business urged to act on male mental health
item.description: Businesses are urged to do more to support workers' health as a report finds mental illness in young men costs the nation $3.3 billion a year in lost productivity.

item.title: Dentists get payback reprieve after audit
item.description: Dentists caught up in an audit of a billion dollar public dental program have been given a reprieve.

item.title: Excessive praise 'risks turning kids into bullies'
item.description: A Melbourne researcher says excessive focus on self-esteem is turning children into narcissistic bullies

item.title: Shares in retreat as Spain, commodities weigh
item.description: Australian stocks are reversing yesterday's gains as Spain's soaring debt costs and falling commodity prices weigh on investor sentiment.

item.title: ASIC issues warning to self-funded retirees
item.description: ASIC wants self-funded retirees to be required to acknowledge that they are not covered by the banking regulator's guarantees following the collapse of Trio Capital.
item.dc:creator: Peter Ryan

item.title: Man loses High Court rape-in-marriage appeal
item.description: The High Court has ruled an elderly man can stand trial for raping his former wife nearly half a century ago.

item.title: Suspended Thomson votes with Coalition
item.description: Tony Abbott and Christopher Pyne scrambled for the exits in the House of Representatives this morning as suspended Labor MP Craig Thomson lent his "tainted" vote to the Opposition.

item.title: Xenophon accuses Labor of gambling backflip
item.description: Independent Senator Nick Xenophon has accused the Federal Government of conducting a "complete about turn" on gambling regulation.

item.title: 'Smoking gun' shot down in Senate estimates
item.description: The Federal Opposition's 'smoking gun' theory about the investigation into suspended Labor MP Craig Thomson appears to have been shot down in Senate estimates.

item.title: Diplomats expelled as Annan tells Assad to stop the killing
item.description: Former UN head Kofi Annan confronts Bashar al-Assad in Damascus as Western nations expel Syrian diplomats, but still the bloodshed in Syria continues.
item.dc:creator: Anne Barker, Brendan Trembath And Rachael Brown

item.title: Union at odds with Bowen on foreign workers
item.description: A major union is at odds with the Federal Government about the number of overseas workers to be brought in for the Roy Hill iron ore project in the Pilbara.

item.title: NSW to transform schools into community hubs
item.description: The NSW Government is transforming 15 schools into community hubs in a bid to lift results in Aboriginal and other disadvantaged communities.

item.title: China won't let growth slow: Emerson
item.description: Australian resource companies could soon be in for a boost from Chinese stimulus measures.

item.title: Appeal for witnesses to nanny's cold case murder
item.description: Detectives investigating the cold case murder of a 21-year-old nanny in western New South Wales are appealing for more witnesses to come forward.

item.title: Search resumes for missing pilot
item.description: The search has resumed for a missing pilot who has not been seen since taking off from an airfield in south-western New South Wales.

item.title: Reds advance to final eight
item.description: Adelaide United progressed to the Asian Champions League quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Nagoya Grampus at Hindmarsh Stadium.

item.title: Industry rallies against national deposit scheme
item.description: Environmentalists say an advertising campaign against a national drink container deposit scheme is a con job because such a scheme has been operating successfully in South Australia for more than 30 years.

item.title: Fairfax to send regional jobs offshore
item.description: Fairfax media is planning to relocate production of its regional newspapers to New Zealand.

item.title: Market pushes higher despite Spanish woes
item.description: The market has posted strong gains for a second straight day.

item.title: Millions lack access to basic financial services
item.description: Nearly 3 million Australians do not have access to basic financial products such as a credit card, car insurance or even a bank account, according to a private study.

item.title: Western nations expel Syrian diplomats
item.description: An Australian move to expel two Syrian diplomats has been followed by Western nations around the world in an effort to pile pressure on president Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Woodley

item.title: Expert backs Government's interim gambling report
item.description: The Federal Government's interim review of Australia's decade-old online gambling laws has recommended legalising some forms of online poker.

item.title: Qantas pulls directors from Air Pacific board
item.description: Qantas has removed its four directors from the board of Air Pacific because it believes the Fijian government wants to take total control of the airline.

item.title: Collapse suggests 'failures across Hastie'
item.description: A corporate law expert says the Hastie Group collapse points to "very significant failures" in the governance of the company that are unlikely to be limited to one division.
item.dc:creator: Simon Lauder

item.title: Fair Work recalled after 'smoking gun' memo surfaces
item.description: Fair Work has been recalled to Senate Estimates amid claims of a "smoking gun" memo which suggested police action be taken against the HSU three years ago.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Woodley

item.title: Lower speed fines but higher demerits for SA
item.description: Fines are being reduced for some speeding motorists in South Australia but demerits points will double.

item.title: Victim relieved as 'grotesque' paedophile jailed
item.description: A man has been jailed over repeated violent rapes of girls during in the 1980s and 90s.

item.title: Housing industry gloomy despite sales upswing
item.description: Sales of new homes rose in April as buyers in Victoria rushed into the market before the axing of that state's first home owner bonus, new figures show.

item.title: Budget cuts expose troops to 'greater harm'
item.description: The Chief of the Army has conceded that one of the Federal Government's Defence cuts will expose troops to greater harm and be more expensive over the long term.

item.title: Caucus backs motion on overseas workers
item.description: Labor Caucus passes a resolution ensuring Australian workers are helped to get mining jobs after a "passionate" debate in the party room.

item.title: Shares look for direction in early trade
item.description: Australian stocks have edged into positive territory in morning trade after mixed leads from European markets overnight, with Wall Street closed for the Memorial Day public holiday.

item.title: Business urges calm in mine visa debate
item.description: Big business is urging Labor MPs not to be swayed by emotional debate about the use of foreign mine workers on Gina Rinehart's Roy Hill project in Western Australia.
item.dc:creator: Peter Ryan

item.title: Gotye dominates APRA Awards
item.description: Gotye takes top honours at the APRA Music Awards, including song of the year for his smash hit Somebody That I Used to Know.

item.title: Gillard to face Caucus over foreign workers plan
item.description: Julia Gillard is facing anger over the deal to import foreign mine workers at Labor Caucus meeting in Canberra this morning.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Hawley

item.title: Army parade boots falling apart in hot weather
item.description: The Australian Defence Force has admitted the rubber soles are falling off the Chinese-made dress boots that soldiers are expected to wear for official parades.

item.title: Hewitt out early, Tomic through
item.description: Iron-willed Lleyton Hewitt made an early French Open exit, while Bernard Tomic picked up his first Roland Garros victory.

item.title: Gillard's personal rating up in Newspoll
item.description: The latest Newspoll shows a four-point surge in the Prime Minister's personal popularity, but the Coalition continues to maintain an election-winning lead.

item.title: Cab driver charged over deadly hit and run
item.description: A Sydney taxi driver has been released on bail after being charged over a fatal hit-and-run in the city's north-west.

item.title: Senior Fair Work official embroiled in HSU fighting
item.description: Kathy Jackson's partner, Fair Work Australia vice-president Michael Lawler, has had direct involvement in the internal politics of the Health Services Union, the ABC has revealed.
item.dc:creator: Chris Uhlmann

item.title: Indigenous program targets mining worker shortages
item.description: A new program is helping change lives for disadvantaged Indigenous Australians by connecting them with mining and construction jobs in the west.
item.dc:creator: Bronwyn Herbert

item.title: Abbott seizes on Labor leadership speculation
item.description: Tony Abbott uses Question Time to seize on the latest outbreak of leadership speculation and internal dissent in Labor over its foreign worker plan.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Kirk

item.title: Jetstar accused of underpaying cabin crew
item.description: Jetstar is being taken to court for allegedly underpaying cabin crew that were recruited in Thailand.

item.title: Share market rallies on Greek vote hopes
item.description: Australian stocks have opened the week with a bang, jumping 1 per cent amid optimism that Greece would remain in the eurozone.

item.title: Greens seek law change for Church abuse victims
item.description: The New South Wales Greens will introduce a private member's bill that would let victims of sex abuse by Catholic clergy sue the property trust that holds much of the church's wealth.

item.title: ACCC set to green light Optus NBN deal
item.description: The competition watchdog has indicated it will approve the $800 million deal for Optus to participate in the high-speed National Broadband Network.

item.title: Fair Work rejects Thomson's interference claim
item.description:
Fair Work Australia has used a Senate estimates hearing to reject allegations its vice-president interfered in its investigation into embattled crossbench MP Craig Thomson.

FWA also says Mr Thomson's claim that he was set up with prostitutes was only raised a few months ago.

Last week in an address to Parliament, Mr Thomson attacked FWA's findings that he misused Health Services Union money on escorts and his election campaign.
item.dc:creator: Sabra Lane

item.title: Shares climb as miners stage comeback
item.description: The Australian share market rose in morning trade despite weak leads from Wall Street on the weekend, as gains among the mining heavyweights supported the broader domestic market.
